comment: Removed the last few lines regarding Indian "love marriages" from Cultural views section. It seems racist/ethnocentric and gives the impression that love is not possible in an arranged marriaged.

diff.*:
Line 85: Line 85:  
[[Image:Love-zh.png|180px|thumb|The traditional [[Chinese character]] for love (愛) consists of a [[heart]] (心, in the middle) inside of "accept", "feel", or "perceive", which shows a graceful emotion.]]
 
[[Image:Love-zh.png|180px|thumb|The traditional [[Chinese character]] for love (愛) consists of a [[heart]] (心, in the middle) inside of "accept", "feel", or "perceive", which shows a graceful emotion.]]
    −
Although there exist numerous cross-cultural unified similarities as to the nature and definition of love, as in there being a thread of commitment, tenderness, and passion common to all human existence, there are differences. According to a newspaper article in ''USA Today'' by Del Hones, love marriages are becoming a popular trend in India, a country whose traditions do not allow dating before marriage <ref>. In Jones' article, ten to twenty percentage of Indians youths who were surveyed reported that their friends are marrying for love, rather than to please their families <ref>. This love marriage trend started in the 1970s and 1980s and is one of the many American exports to eastern countries <ref>.
+
Although there exist numerous cross-cultural unified similarities as to the nature and definition of love, as in there being a thread of commitment, tenderness, and passion common to all human existence, there are differences.
